title: Splurges & Treats
description: Explore how you think about indulging and treating yourselves.

questions.text: When it comes to splurging, I tend to...
choices: Rarely do it—I feel guilty spending on extras
Do it occasionally when something feels special
Enjoy it—life's too short not to
Only when I feel we've earned it

therapeutic.rationale: Splurging tendencies reveal our relationship with pleasure and guilt. Rarely-splurgers feel guilty; occasional types balance; enjoyers embrace pleasure; earners need justification. Partners often have different comfort with indulgence.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The enjoyer may feel the rarely-splurger is depriving themselves; the rarely-splurger may feel the enjoyer is irresponsible. Both are managing different emotional relationships with spending.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared splurging tendencies mean you'll naturally agree on when indulgence is okay.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel after you splurge on something? Satisfied? Guilty? Where does that feeling come from?

questions.text: The things worth splurging on for me are...
choices: Experiences and travel
Quality items that last
Food and dining
Hobbies and personal interests

therapeutic.rationale: Splurge categories reveal joy sources. Experience-lovers value memories; quality-buyers value durability; food-lovers value pleasure; hobby-spenders value passion. Knowing your partner's joy-spending helps you support it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different splurge values may feel like the other doesn't understand what brings you joy. Share why these things matter to you—not just that they do.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared splurge priorities make treats feel mutual. You naturally want to indulge in the same ways.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's something you love splurging on? What makes it worth it to you?

questions.text: When my partner wants to splurge on something, I usually...
choices: Support it—their joy matters to me
Think about whether we can afford it
Want to understand why it matters to them
Feel fine as long as it's their money

therapeutic.rationale: Reactions to partner splurging reveal trust, boundaries, and values. Supporters prioritize joy; affordability-checkers prioritize security; understanders seek connection; autonomy-granters respect independence. These reactions shape money dynamics.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The supporter may feel the affordability-checker is controlling; the affordability-checker may feel the supporter doesn't take finances seriously. Both care—about different things.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reactions mean you'll respond to each other's splurges similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner wants to spend on something you wouldn't? What do you do with that feeling?

questions.text: Treating each other is something I think we should...
choices: Do often—it shows love and appreciation
Do occasionally to keep it special
Not worry about—we share everything anyway
Balance—sometimes me, sometimes you

therapeutic.rationale: Treating philosophy reveals love expression values. Frequent-treaters show love through gifts; occasional-treaters preserve meaning; sharers see no distinction; balancers track reciprocity. Partners may have different philosophies.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The frequent-treater may feel the occasional-treater doesn't show love; the occasional-treater may feel the frequent-treater is excessive. Understand what treating means to each of you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared treating philosophy makes gift-giving easy and meaningful.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does it mean to you when your partner treats you? What does it mean when you treat them?

questions.text: After a splurge, I typically feel...
choices: Happy—it was worth it
A bit of buyer's remorse
Depends on what it was
Ready to get back on track financially

therapeutic.rationale: Post-splurge feelings reveal emotional patterns. Happy-feelers have peace with pleasure; remorse-feelers have guilt; depends-types are context-driven; back-on-trackers feel temporary deviation. These patterns affect enjoyment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The happy-feeler may not understand the remorse-feeler's guilt; the remorse-feeler may envy the happy-feeler's peace. Share what's behind your post-splurge feelings.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared post-splurge feelings mean you process indulgence similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you feel after you buy something special for yourself? What would help you feel better about it?
